summary: Bullied by classmates, young Max (Cayden Boyd) escapes into a fantasy, conjuring up the action-packed lives of Lavagirl (Taylor Dooley) and Sharkboy (Taylor Lautner). But one day, Lavagirl and Sharkboy suddenly come to life -- and their world, Planet Drool, needs a hero named Max. As Max escapes to Planet Drool, he battles aliens and tries to save his new friends' planet from destruction. He also battles his bullies, who have become villains like the Ice Princess (Sasha Pieterse).

reviews.content: A hilariously cheesy movie that is worth watching to see how silly it is. Creative and filled with eccentric ideas, but lacks in emotional impact and wit. Definitely one of those 'so bad it's good' movies.

It sets up this dynamic about the power of imagination to eventually turn out to be a cliche mess with dated visuals. Sharkboi and Lavagrrril thoroughly captures the Heroes Journey, there are indeed heroes and they in fact go on a journey. Never before has there been such a story on the big screen. Something that can not be said about the Squeaquel, as Spankboi and Lovagrril have already been on the big screen. As the the creator of Shankboi ( but not lavaagrell) I feel the the spin-off where I turn Sharbopy into a wherewolf was the true squeaquel.

Bad watch, won't watch again, and can't recommend.  (Maybe for younger audiences)

I understand that this is supposed to be a "power of imagination" kids story, but there is just a lot of garbage in this.

The kids seem to do some fairly good acting for what they're asked to do, but I'm not sure why George Lopez was cast, but the writing is weak enough that it could easily just be the writing.

The story is designed to look like it's just literally written haphazardly as they go, so it's hard to tell what's badly written, and what's correctly written to make it look like bad kid writing.

While the characters of Sharkboy (especially) and Lavagirl are quite ridiculous, there are some fun things that they include throughout the movie, so its not like the movie is completely without quality, but piled together it was not an experience I'd want to do again.

I have never in my life seen a movie this "modern" and SOOOO sexist on every level. Our kids are not allowed to this again. Sexist comments, the way they portrait this girl as a sex object when she is like 12(?), terrible. 

Only way to recommend this is in education purpose on how NOT to do a movie.

A movie clearly destined only for kids, but not everyone else. With dated cgi, wooden acting, a silly plot and a narrative about the power of imagination and believing in yourself that ends up being generic and clich√©. This movie made my childhood. I blame it for planting the seeds for my current love of science fiction, comic books and character design. I had so many fun, imaginary adventures as a kid with my friends because I wanted to pretend I could make whole worlds like Max did. It still brings me joy to rewatch some of my favorite parts of the movie.

Of course critics and most adults don't like it, because it's for kids. It's for kids who want to believe in magic and that maybe, in some distant place, their dreams could really come true. It's for kids who feel like outsiders. For kids who want to escape but don't quite have the words to say it. You might not get it but please, let your kids watch sharkboy and lavagirl.

This may be a hit for an absolute brainless kids movie, but as far as anything else goes, this movie tanks!

It had a great plot line of the student trying to steal away the dream world and destroy everything. The one thing I did not like in the movie was the destruction of the dream character, "Mr. Electric." I would have rather seen him be co-teachers with Mr. Electricidad due to what was seen through the movie the character had what appeared a passion for giving scientific facts and asking questions a home teacher would ask. Also he made it known he did not like the job he was given in the dreamland so it would have been great to see in the end Mr. Electricidad, played by non other then George Lopez, to offer Mr. Electric a teaching partnership or act on his behalf as a substitute teacher. It would have really brought it together. Overall, I was very impressed with the movie and will be watched again and again by the kids.

The Adventures of Shark-boy and Lava-girl in 3-D is one of the great transcendent masterpieces ever filmed. One of the most masterful touches is that the green screens in the background are very obvious to the eye; in this way, the film breaks the fourth-wall and offers intelligent meta-commentary on the nature of film in the process, harshly critiquing the low quality production values present in much of animated cinema. Another instance of this meta-commentary lies in the intentionally absurd dialogue, and here the film switches it's focus to the action-thriller genre, brilliantly and carefully picking apart the awful lines screenwriters offer to actors in the modern Hollywood Blockbuster. Sharkboy and Lavagirl's commentary goes deeper than just the movies however, with the tribulations that the two titular characters go through exposing the struggles experiences by all Shark-boys and Lava-girls worldwide, and it's constantly changing and often incoherent plot representing the horror of memory loss. In short, this film is masterful.

The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3D is a family must watch. The character work in this film is amazing I must applaud Robert Rodriguez his work in this film is far superior to his work in The Spy Kids franchise. The idea to base this of his children's dreams is a masterful stroke of genius that is far better then these unoriginal superheros films. The song dream, dream, dream is far better than any Disney song and any music that the chart toppers are putting out toady. The villain of this film Minus brilliantly portrayed by Jacob Davich is so layered and complex he is up there with the greats. Everyone must go see this film.

A movie like this is hard to comprehend. Its existence isn't unbelievable. It came right off the Spy Kids movies, and took all the worst things from them and cranked it to the max. And sure, the imagination aspect of it is cute, but everything else about it is beyond awful. There's too many good alternatives to this for it to be worth trying if you were a kid in the 2000s. Even the original Spy Kids movies are better and have about the same feel to them.
It's also one of those early 3d movies that think 3D = launch cg goop at the screen constantly.

"The Adventure of Sharkboy and Lavagirl" still remains to be a classical and pivotal movie for us all. The movie was not just a source of entertainment, but it provided us a door into our own imagination - from providing us with a powerful villain such as, Mr. Electric, to giving us an escape to the dream world with a little help from the iconic song, Dream Song. The movie showed us how powerful our imagination is and how we must not let it go, no matter where life takes us. As we grow up, we start to hate life and people, so we resort to netflix and/or our idols as a source of escape. But we must not forget, as we continue to isolate ourselves because of the annoying people in our lives, the problems we face, or just because twitter shows it as "mainstream," we must follow in the footsteps of Max; we must create our own Dreamland. Despite the life lessons I was taught to soon, the hauntings and nightmares I have experienced because of the tragic defeat of Mr. Electric, I will not give this movie five stars.

This film is nothing short of a masterpiece. Anyone who says otherwise lacks the rare intellect required to truly be invested in the film. The characters develop over time, fixing their flaws or learning to live with them, a great message to our nations children.

Boy, is this movie bad. There is some fridge brilliance and there's that memetic line about ruining dream journals. It is kind of cute that Robert Rodriguez made this movie for his kids. But this movie is still not very good. The acting is bad with Taylor Lautner stuck with a constant frown on his face and the parents clearly not caring. Everyone is either dull surprise or over-the-top. The CGI, while bright and colourful is so conspicuous that it's fake. Unlike the other digital backlot Rodriguez-directed movie that came out in 2005, Sin City, the greenscreen looks terrible. Planet Drool isn't supposed to be real but you don't see kids on a planet, you see kids in front of a green-screen that shows a planet. There are a few really bad jokes. For instance, one of our main villains, Mr. Electric makes a few bad puns...and explains them. Batman & Robin was full of bad puns but at least we didn't have to deal with them explaining it because viewers are morons. Sharkboy and Lavagirl is terrible, yes but it wasn't really meant for me or anyone. It's a present from Robert Rodriguez to one of his kids. And it's a cute present, if a lousy movie.

I personally have no real problem with 3D, as long as it is done well and has a good story and characters. Sadly, that's where The Adventures of SharkBoy and Lava Girl fails. I like Robert Rodriguez and thought his first two Spy Kids movies were very enjoyable and while mediocre I actually thought the third Spy Kids film was better than this too. I will give some credit, the moral is decent if hardly original and there is some energy. But everything else falls flat.

People might say the art direction was colourful and pleasing to the eye. Sorry, for me it was very tacky, gaudy and brash. And as for the 3D, it is actually some of the worst I've seen, it needed more clarity and sharpness and sometimes moved too fast. Also I found it distracting in alternative to enhancing. The soundtrack is rather plodding, generic and unmemorable too.

The script is absolutely awful too. Any parts that tried to be funny made me roll my eyes to be perfectly honest with you, while the story is unevenly paced and very weak and predictable. The characters are just as weak and bland too, the two main characters have their likable moments but there is little chemistry between them and the audience while the supporting characters fare even worse suffering either from being underused or overacted. Overall, the acting is very uneven and way too broad in some cases.

Other disappointments are the poor pace and plodding direction from Rodriguez. So in conclusion, the result is a pretty awful, overstuffed and disappointing effort of a family film. 1/10 Bethany Cox

A young boy has crazy dreams that he tracks in a journal.  Most of his dreams are about two children, Sharboy and Lavagirl, who live on a planet with good and evil.  One inauspicious day the dreaming boy is whisked off to their planet to try and help them save it from an evil villain.

"I'm not evil, am I Max?"
"I don't think so..."

Robert Rodriguez, director of The Faculty, Desperado, Spy Kids 1-3, Sin City, Once Upon a Time in Mexico, Machete, El Mariachi, and Planet Terror, delivers The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl.  The storyline for this picture is dreadful as are the special effects for the most part.  The acting is also below par, even for the genre. 

"He's going to try and destroy you in your sleep."

I came across this film on Netflix and never really had an interest in watching it.  I decided to watch it with my daughter and discovered this is as bad as historically reviewed.  This is a miserable addition to the genre and I'd skip it unless nothing else is available.

"Some dreams are so powerful they become real."

Grade: D

A majority of this movie takes place on a planet titled "Planet Drool" (Full name: "Planet So Cool You Will Drool")  so right there that should tick you off that this isn't a film that really caters to an adult crowd. Still I felt that the movie was imaginitive and pretty fun . Most of the film takes place on Planet Drool, which is almost entirely rendered in CGI, seeing the actors interact with a pure CGI enviornent is kinda endearing and it gives the movie a whole otherworldiness. It's not great art, but if you know what you're getting into you should have a fun time.

Sharkboy and Lavagirl, a highlight favorite of my friends when they were younger, suggested I watched this one because it doesn't hold up nearly as much watching it now. Honestly, I can disagree - it's corny, it's cheesy, it's undeniably cheap but it's sheer fun with decent characters.
A boy named Max dreams up a superhero combo, Sharkboy and Lavagirl, to, above helping his undesirable personal life, to save Drool City from becoming too dark and overruled by the evil Mr. Electric and his higher power Linus. 
The story was created by Rodriguez' kids and well, it shows clearly. It's not a great formula in terms of good filmmaking but in making box office cash, it's a decent plan. Nonetheless, the film is fun, albeit raising a lot of questions, having some noticably poor CGI here and there, bombarded with greenscreen all over, and I didn't particularly like Lautner's performance - most but not all of this is made up with its fun atmosphere and characters with a relatable childlike atmosphere to it. To answer my friends who said it doesn't hold up so well, it doesn't, even with nostalgic value, but it's still a fun joyride that is hard to look at a ton of flaws for.
Loved this movie as a kid. But now, it's so cringeworthy. I can barely get through it all. Though I have to say that it definitely has some of the best 3D out there.

I recently watched sharkboy and lavagirl again as a teenager and was just appalled. First off, the cgi is god awful in this film and it looked as though it was made for a toys r us advert! The whole concept is just f@!&ing bulls%^t and honestly could've been written by a 5 year old. Some may argue in saying that it was built for young children and it is and many children and toddlers enjoy it. But the kid films that really entertain are the one's that are built for ALL ages. Why do you think disney/pixar films are so popular? So, sharkboy and lavagirl is a good film to put on for your children when they are very young but if they decide to watch it again when they are older like me...they're probably going to be disappointed.

The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl was a film I watched as a child. We loved how blatantly ridiculous it all was, And you know what? I still do. 

The acting is terrible, the dialogue; dribble, the script appalling, the special effects laughable, the messages preposterous, the creativity bogged and the direction incompetent. All faults, and there are many of them, aside this film is not unwatchable. In fact, what makes this film so fun is how bad it is, and the lack of cynicism evident in much worse fare like Epic Movie and Disaster Movie.

Everything is so, so, so, so, so,so, so, so badly miscalculated that this film acts as an entertaining guide on how NOT to make a film. This film is like trying to bake a vanilla cake, burning it, and passing it off as chocolate. And everyone likes chocolate. This film defines the so-bad-its-good genre.

If you could sum up Sharkboy and Lavagirl in as many words as its title (8): Diabolically wretched storytelling in a severely miscalculated classic.
Just don't! You'll thank me later.

The acting was not good at all, and the characters were so clich√© and boring. The effects are really terrible at times, and this movie is only a decade old. The plot holes are plentiful, in a story that makes little to no sense. The characters do things normal people wouldn't do, the dialogue is occasionally cringe worthy, and there is very little for me to enjoy in this movie, its terribly written with a stupid story awful effects and laughable scenes (what did I se in this as a kid!?) The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl gets 1/5 stars (D-).

A Quickie Review

The first two "Spy Kids" movies were great; the third one, not so much.  However, even that was better than this mess, which suffers from cheesy special effects and an inane plot.  Though this movie has become popular recently thanks to Taylor Lautner appearing in "Twilight," I can't imagine that even fans of that vampire romance would like this, unless they can't refrain from drooling over Jacob Black in any form.

Content Concerns:

    Sex: None. 5/5
    Nudity: Mild cleavage. 4.75/5
    Language: Some name-calling. 4.5/5
    Drugs: None. 5/5
    Violence: Plenty of "TV-Y7"-style fantasy violence is present here.  The kids fight against alien enemies, but there is no blood or gore.  Also, some of the bullying involves kids throwing things at each other. 4/5
    Frightening/Intense Scenes: Some of the monsters and other beings on the "dream planet" could scare some kids; I particularly thought the computer-generated fish were hideous. 3/5
    Other: Some crude humor is present. 4/5

Score: 1.75/5

This may sound shocking, but I found this odd-titled film half enjoyable, despite the overall feel like it was rushed through production, with no care whatsoever in the creation of numerous poke-you-in-the-eye 3D effects. As with the superior "Spy Kids" several years before, "Sharkboy and Lavagirl" works because of its INTENTIONAL cheesiness, its fun stab at interpreting children's intricate imaginations, and the inherent, humorous mockery of director Robert Rodriguez. Our main hero is a young boy who wants the simplest thing possible, the permission to dream and use his imagination, (which also happens to be the singular thing society and the educational system seeks to squash from the youngest age demographics.) Max is no loud-mouth, no smart-aleck, no "see-I-told-you-my-dreams-were-real-now-say-sorry" type of brat, but a quiet, "artsy" type who we've all met before. (Maybe we WERE him, long ago.) His two prized creations of Sharkboy and Lavagirl are always there to help despite their occasional quarrelling, and their quirky appearances and actions are, for lack of a better word, ridiculous. If they were anything else, I would have been sorely disappointed in the film. Characters become frozen into ice blocks and used as bobsleds to escape enemies; characters are attacked by electric eels and hunted down by giant electrical outlets; characters sleepwalk on queue, stop moving rollercoaster cars with their legs, shoot butterflies into each other's faces, sing rap-lullabies, and float downstream on giant chocolate-chip cookies. Childishly imaginative, unaboundedly silly. This is the type of fantasy "The Never Ending Story" wishes it was. However, despite a great start and even greater potential to be a classic, "Sharkboy and Lavagirl" ultimately is disjointed, its message of pro-imagination never fully-realized. All loose plot-threads are neatly tied by the final scene, but there is no sensible logic as to how they have been tied. In addition, as stated in the beginning of this review, much of the fanciful world of Planet Drool had been created within a computer, and the generally-bad quality of special effects detract from the fish boy and molten girl's antics. I believe the film could have been more successful if it had followed closer in the footsteps of Spy Kids: less visual blare, less moving around, less focus on getting the job done, and MORE absurd interactions between featuring flesh-and-blood actors and physical props.
One of the worst kid films ever made.
